title: How to prove that |a+b| = |a|+|b| if ab is greater than or equal to 0 - Quora

response.answer_text: Triangle Inequality: For any two real numbers [math]a,b;[/math]the following inequality holds : [math]|a+b|\leq |a|+|b|\:;[/math]with equality holding if and only if [math]ab\geq 0\:[/math]or in simpler sense both [math]a,b\:[/math]have the same sign.  To prove the triangle inequality and checking when the equality holds, we use the following fact For [math]m,n \in \R^+; m<n \iff m^2<n^2[/math] Thus, to prove the triangle inequality ; it suffices to verify : [math]\:\:\:\:\:\:\:\:\:|a+b|^2\leq \big(|a|+|b|\big)^2[/math] [math]\iff a^2+2ab+b^2\leq a^2+b^2+2|ab|[/math] [math]\iff ab\leq |ab|\:[/math](This is true.) Now in the above inequality, equality holds if and only if [math]ab\geq 0.[/math] We simply used the fact that for [math]x\in \R; |x|\geq x \:[/math]and that [math]|x|=x [/math]if and only if [math]x\geq 0.[/math]Retracing our inequalities bottom to top, the triangle inequality is proved with equality holding if and only if [math]\:ab\geq 0 . \:\blacksquare[/math]
